document.docAuthor: De Assis, Jose Eriberto, de Brito, Rafael Justino, Christoffersen, Martin Lindsey & de Souza, Jose Roberto Botelho
document.masterDocTitle: A catalogue of the scaleworm genus Lepidonotus (Polynoidae, Polychaeta) from South America, with two new records for Brazilian waters

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A catalogue of the scaleworm genus Lepidonotus (Polynoidae, Polychaeta) from South America, with two new records for Brazilian waters

subSubSection.paragraph:
Lepidonotus caeloris .- Moore 1903 : 412-414, pl. 23: fig. 12 (Japan, 115-280 m), 1906 : 546-547, pl. 36: figs 36-37 (Alaska); 1908 : 331 (Alaska and Pacific Canada), 1910 : 333-334 (California).- Essenberg 1918 : 184 (Alaska to California, 53-932 m).- Hartman and Reish 1950 : 5 (Oregon).-
Diaz-Castaneda and Rodriguez-Villanueva 1998
: 12 (Pacific Mexico).

Lepidonotus caelorus .- Treadwell 1914 : 182 (California).- Chamberlin 1918 : 174 (California).- Berkeley 1923 : 213 (Pacific Canada).- Hartman 1939 : 44, 1944 : 244 (California).- Rioja 1941 : 680 (Pacific Mexico), 1947 : 199 (Pacific Mexico).- Berkeley and Berkeley 1942 (Alaska).- Pettibone 1953 : 15-16, pl. 1: figs 1-8; pl. 2: figs 9-19 (Washington and Oregon 7.3-256 m, with
Volsella modiolus
,
Balanus nubilis
, on tube of
Neosabella
[as
Sabellaria
]
cementarium
, in calcareous tubes of Dodecaceria " pacifica " ).- Reish 1968 : 100 (California).
Lepidonotus coelorus .- Treadwell 1937 : 141 (California).- Berkeley and Berkeley 1942 : 187 (Pacific Canada), 1948 : 9-10, figs 6-7 (Pacific Canada).- Pequegnat 1964 : 278 (California).
Western Pacific from Japan. Eastern Pacific from Alaska to California. Southwestern Atlantic from Paraiba to Sao Paulo. 7.3-932 m (Figure 1 ).

.

subSubSection.paragraph:
The species occurs in colonies of the sponge
Zygomycale parishii
(Bowerbank, 1875), in colonies of the bryozoan
Schizoporella errata
(Waters, 1879), on tubes of sabellariid
Neosabellaria cementarium
(Moore, 1906), in tubes of cirratulid Dodecaceria " pacifica " , with the barnacle
Balanus nubilis
(Darwin, 1854), and the mussel
Volsella modiolus
. In rhodolith beds.

Lepidonotus caeruleus
presents a wide distribution. Futher studies are required to enable us to understand if it is a cryptogenic species, because there are no studies to show that it represents a species complex, and its origin was not determined.
